elements.content: Structural analyses of a flexible 1D MOF [Cu­(BF4)2(bpp)2] (bpp =1,3-bis­(4-pyridyl)­propane) with/without guest molecules were performed by synchrotron powder X-ray diffraction analysis and single crystal structural analysis. The guest-free MOF is composed of 1D chains composed of Cu­(II) ions and bpp ligands which are accumulated to form quasi-2D layers, resulting in a quasi-layered compound. The guest-free MOF has no open pore windows; it, however, has latent quasi-hexagonal cavities surrounded by six BF4 anions. This MOF shows molecular selective sorption, which stems from guest-dependent dynamic structural transformation including pore-opening/closing processes. It shows selective alcohol sorption based on the molecular recognition properties; it sorbs C1–C3 alcohols, but not a C4 alcohol (1-butanol). Sorption properties can be enhanced by accumulation of several functionalities. In the case of the flexible MOF, the sorption properties should be synergetically enhanced by several key properties; it has molecular recognition properties and accommodate selected species with pore-opening, and furthermore prevent other species from entering cavities by pore-closing.
elements.clean_text: Structural analyses of a flexible 1D MOF [Cu(BF4)2(bpp)2] (bpp =1,3-bis(4-pyridyl)propane) with/without guest molecules were performed by synchrotron powder X-ray diffraction analysis and single crystal structural analysis. The guest-free MOF is composed of 1D chains composed of Cu(II) ions and bpp ligands which are accumulated to form quasi-2D layers, resulting in a quasi-layered compound. The guest-free MOF has no open pore windows; it, however, has latent quasi-hexagonal cavities surrounded by six BF4 anions. This MOF shows molecular selective sorption, which stems from guest-dependent dynamic structural transformation including pore-opening/closing processes. It shows selective alcohol sorption based on the molecular recognition properties; it sorbs C1-C3 alcohols, but not a C4 alcohol (1-butanol). Sorption properties can be enhanced by accumulation of several functionalities. In the case of the flexible MOF, the sorption properties should be synergetically enhanced by several key properties; it has molecular recognition properties and accommodate selected species with pore-opening, and furthermore prevent other species from entering cavities by pore-closing.

elements.content: Molecular separation, especially selective separation of target molecules from a mixture of molecules with similar sizes and shapes is a key technology in various industrial fields, and new porous materials and new processes related to the separation have been intensively studied for further development of the technology. Microporous materials are useful for molecular adsorption/separation because of their high specific surface areas, deep potential well with the overlap of interactions from pore walls, and pore functionalities. Carbon materials and zeolites have been widely used in industries, and recently metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) or porous coordination polymers, which are crystalline organic–inorganic hybrid materials with tunable pore properties (i.e., pore size/shape and pore surface functionalities), have emerged as promising porous materials for a variety of application properties such as sensing, magnetism, catalysis, and ion exchange as well as molecular sorption/separation.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Molecular separation, especially selective separation of target molecules from a mixture of molecules with similar sizes and shapes is a key technology in various industrial fields, and new porous materials and new processes related to the separation have been intensively studied for further development of the technology. Microporous materials are useful for molecular adsorption/separation because of their high specific surface areas, deep potential well with the overlap of interactions from pore walls, and pore functionalities. Carbon materials and zeolites have been widely used in industries, and recently metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) or porous coordination polymers, which are crystalline organic-inorganic hybrid materials with tunable pore properties (i.e., pore size/shape and pore surface functionalities), have emerged as promising porous materials for a variety of application properties such as sensing, magnetism, catalysis, and ion exchange as well as molecular sorption/separation.

elements.content: Among MOFs, some flexible MOFs show unique and excellent sorption/separation abilities, which should stem from flexibility of coordination bonds and of organic ligands, and/or weak interactions between framework motifs. For example, Co­(BDP) (BDP = 1,4-benzenedipyrazolate) represents a stepwise N2 sorption isotherm through five-step phase transition, and furthermore shows a stepwise H2 sorption isotherm with a hysteresis loop, which allows us to store H2 molecules at a pressure lower than that of sorption. A 2D layered MOF [Cu­(BF4)2(bpy)2] (ELM-11) (bpy = 4,4′-bipyridine) shows expansion/shrinkage structural transformation through CO2 gate adsorption/desorption at 273 K because of weak interlayer interactions, and no response to N2 at the similar condition, resulting in high CO2/N2 selectivity. These facts indicate the effectiveness of structural flexibility of MOFs for selective sorption/separation as well as the modification of the structure and pore properties.
elements.clean_text: Among MOFs, some flexible MOFs show unique and excellent sorption/separation abilities, which should stem from flexibility of coordination bonds and of organic ligands, and/or weak interactions between framework motifs. For example, Co(BDP) (BDP = 1,4-benzenedipyrazolate) represents a stepwise N2 sorption isotherm through five-step phase transition, and furthermore shows a stepwise H2 sorption isotherm with a hysteresis loop, which allows us to store H2 molecules at a pressure lower than that of sorption. A 2D layered MOF [Cu(BF4)2(bpy)2] (ELM-11) (bpy = 4,4'-bipyridine) shows expansion/shrinkage structural transformation through CO2 gate adsorption/desorption at 273 K because of weak interlayer interactions, and no response to N2 at the similar condition, resulting in high CO2/N2 selectivity. These facts indicate the effectiveness of structural flexibility of MOFs for selective sorption/separation as well as the modification of the structure and pore properties.

elements.content: Since it is expected that guest molecules form a regular array in ordered nanospace of MOFs, the X-ray techniques should be useful to investigate host–guest relationship in MOF systems. In addition, it is known that the atoms/molecules accommodated in a restricted nanospace indicate abnormal freezing/melting behaviors and electric and magnetic properties. Therefore, structural analysis of flexible MOFs with guest molecules is important not only for better understanding of flexible MOFs but also for further development of functional porous materials to design atomic/molecular arrangement in nanospace.
elements.clean_text: Since it is expected that guest molecules form a regular array in ordered nanospace of MOFs, the X-ray techniques should be useful to investigate host-guest relationship in MOF systems. In addition, it is known that the atoms/molecules accommodated in a restricted nanospace indicate abnormal freezing/melting behaviors and electric and magnetic properties. Therefore, structural analysis of flexible MOFs with guest molecules is important not only for better understanding of flexible MOFs but also for further development of functional porous materials to design atomic/molecular arrangement in nanospace.

elements.content: Previously, we reported a flexible 1D MOF [Cu­(BF4)2(bpp)2] (bpp = 1,3-bis­(4-pyridyl)­propane) showing selective CO2 gate adsorption properties. The MOF indicated CO2 gate adsorption at around room temperature below 1 atm and on the other hand no uptake of N2 under similar conditions. It is also reported by another group that the material exhibited high CO2 separation abilities from CH4/CO2 mixtures under kinetic conditions. However, it remains unclear why the 1D MOF shows such unique sorption/separation properties.
elements.clean_text: Previously, we reported a flexible 1D MOF [Cu(BF4)2(bpp)2] (bpp = 1,3-bis(4-pyridyl)propane) showing selective CO2 gate adsorption properties. The MOF indicated CO2 gate adsorption at around room temperature below 1 atm and on the other hand no uptake of N2 under similar conditions. It is also reported by another group that the material exhibited high CO2 separation abilities from CH4/CO2 mixtures under kinetic conditions. However, it remains unclear why the 1D MOF shows such unique sorption/separation properties.

elements.content: Here, we propose a mechanism of the gate adsorption on the flexible 1D MOF based on detailed crystal structure analyses with/without guest molecules. The structural analyses revealed that the guest-free state of the 1D MOF has quasi-hexagonal latent cavities, which have no open windows, and selectively accommodates guest molecules in the cavities through pore-opening/closing processes induced by host–guest interaction (). The pore-closing prevents molecules other than interactive molecules capable to open the pore entrance from entering into the pores, which is reasonable to enhance molecular selectivity. The MOF shows selective alcohol sorption based on the molecular recognition properties; the MOF sorbs C1–C3 alcohols and no C4 alcohol (1-butanol). Accumulation of functionalities such as selective pore-opening/closing and molecular recognition properties must be important for synergistic enhancement of sorption properties of flexible MOFs.
elements.clean_text: Here, we propose a mechanism of the gate adsorption on the flexible 1D MOF based on detailed crystal structure analyses with/without guest molecules. The structural analyses revealed that the guest-free state of the 1D MOF has quasi-hexagonal latent cavities, which have no open windows, and selectively accommodates guest molecules in the cavities through pore-opening/closing processes induced by host-guest interaction (). The pore-closing prevents molecules other than interactive molecules capable to open the pore entrance from entering into the pores, which is reasonable to enhance molecular selectivity. The MOF shows selective alcohol sorption based on the molecular recognition properties; the MOF sorbs C1-C3 alcohols and no C4 alcohol (1-butanol). Accumulation of functionalities such as selective pore-opening/closing and molecular recognition properties must be important for synergistic enhancement of sorption properties of flexible MOFs.

elements.content: Schematic model of the selective dynamic accommodation process. Green blocks represent BF4 anions. Red circle and gray octahedron mean sorbable and nonsorbable species, respectively.
elements.clean_text: 1  Schematic model of the selective dynamic accommodation process. Green blocks represent BF4 anions. Red circle and gray octahedron mean sorbable and nonsorbable species, respectively.

elements.content: Crystalline powder of guest-free [Cu­(BF4)2(bpp)2] (1) was obtained as follows. An ethanol solution of bpp (80 mM, 5 mL) was added to an aqueous solution of Cu­(BF4)2·6H2O (40 mM, 5 mL) under stirring. Purple microcrystals obtained several hours later were washed with ethanol and dried by suction filtration for 30 min.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Methods

Crystalline powder of guest-free [Cu(BF4)2(bpp)2] (1) was obtained as follows. An ethanol solution of bpp (80 mM, 5 mL) was added to an aqueous solution of Cu(BF4)2⋅6H2O (40 mM, 5 mL) under stirring. Purple microcrystals obtained several hours later were washed with ethanol and dried by suction filtration for 30 min.

elements.content: Single crystals of {[Cu­(BF4)2(bpp)2]·2­(CH3CH­(OH)­CH3)} (1­(2-PrOH)*), which contain 2-propanol as guest molecules, were synthesized as follows. An asterisk is put on the name to refer to single crystal results to distinguish from powder crystal results. A 2-propanol solution of bpp (80 mM, 5 mL) was added onto an aqueous solution of Cu­(BF4)2·6H2O (40 mM, 5 mL) after adding 2-propanol (2 mL) as an intermediate solvent in a test tube at a room temperature. After a few days, purple crystals were grown on the tube wall, and then collected by suction filtration and washed with 2-propanol.
elements.clean_text: Single crystals of {[Cu(BF4)2(bpp)2]⋅2(CH3CH(OH)CH3)} (1(2-PrOH)*), which contain 2-propanol as guest molecules, were synthesized as follows. An asterisk is put on the name to refer to single crystal results to distinguish from powder crystal results. A 2-propanol solution of bpp (80 mM, 5 mL) was added onto an aqueous solution of Cu(BF4)2⋅6H2O (40 mM, 5 mL) after adding 2-propanol (2 mL) as an intermediate solvent in a test tube at a room temperature. After a few days, purple crystals were grown on the tube wall, and then collected by suction filtration and washed with 2-propanol.

elements.content: The synchrotron XRD patterns of guest-free 1 and 1 with gas/vapor loading were measured at BL02B2 SPring-8 with a large Debye–Scherrer camera. In situ XRD measurements were performed on 1 with loading of CO2 at 273 K and with alcohol vapors at 303 K. The wavelength of the incident X-ray were 0.79967(2) and 0.80008(2) Å, respectively. Before all the in situ XRD measurements, 1 was evacuated at 343 K for 2 h. The samples 1 with CO2 at 101 kPa, methanol vapor at 10 kPa, ethanol vapor at 6.7 kPa, 1-propanol vapor at 2 kPa, 2-propanol vapor at 4 kPa, and 1-butanol vapor at 0.5 kPa are described as 1(CO2), 1­(MeOH), 1­(EtOH), 1­(1-PrOH), 1­(2-PrOH), and 1­(BuOH), respectively.
elements.clean_text: The synchrotron XRD patterns of guest-free 1 and 1 with gas/vapor loading were measured at BL02B2 SPring-8 with a large Debye-Scherrer camera. In situ XRD measurements were performed on 1 with loading of CO2 at 273 K and with alcohol vapors at 303 K. The wavelength of the incident X-ray were 0.79967(2) and 0.80008(2) Å, respectively. Before all the in situ XRD measurements, 1 was evacuated at 343 K for 2 h. The samples 1 with CO2 at 101 kPa, methanol vapor at 10 kPa, ethanol vapor at 6.7 kPa, 1-propanol vapor at 2 kPa, 2-propanol vapor at 4 kPa, and 1-butanol vapor at 0.5 kPa are described as 1(CO2), 1(MeOH), 1(EtOH), 1(1-PrOH), 1(2-PrOH), and 1(BuOH), respectively.

elements.content: The lattice parameters of 1­(MeOH), 1­(1-PrOH), and 1­(2-PrOH) were obtained from the synchrotron XRD patterns by using the program NTREOR and refined in the Le Bail method using EXPO2009 software. The structural analyses of 1, 1­(CO 2 ), and 1­(EtOH) were performed with the extracted intensities in the Le Bail method by a direct method using EXPO2009, and refined by Rietveld method using RIETAN-FP. The site occupancies of CO2 and ethanol molecules were fixed to be 0.7 and 0.9, respectively, based on the results of sorption measurement.
elements.clean_text: The lattice parameters of 1(MeOH), 1(1-PrOH), and 1(2-PrOH) were obtained from the synchrotron XRD patterns by using the program NTREOR and refined in the Le Bail method using EXPO2009 software. The structural analyses of 1, 1(CO  2  ), and 1(EtOH) were performed with the extracted intensities in the Le Bail method by a direct method using EXPO2009, and refined by Rietveld method using RIETAN-FP. The site occupancies of CO2 and ethanol molecules were fixed to be 0.7 and 0.9, respectively, based on the results of sorption measurement.

elements.content: Single crystal XRD of 1­(2-PrOH)* was measured at 173 K by R-AXIS RAPID (Rigaku) with monochromated Cu Kα radiation at 50 mA and 250 kV. The structure was solved by the direct method (SIR97) and refined by full matrix least-squares on F 2 (SHELX97). Anisotropic displacement parameters were assigned to all the non-hydrogen atoms. The crystal structure of 1­(2-PrOH)* can be basically expected to be the same to that of 1­(2-PrOH) supported by the similarity of XRD patterns although there are slight shifts of the diffraction peaks in XRD patterns of them due to the different measurement temperatures. Crystallographic parameters of 1, 1­(CO 2 ), 1­(MeOH), 1­(EtOH), 1­(1-PrOH), 1­(2-PrOH), and 1­(2-PrOH)* are summarized in . CCDC 1479332 (1­(CO 2 )), 1479333 (1), 1479334 (1­(EtOH)), and 1484688 (1­(2-PrOH)*) contain the supplementary crystallographic data. These data can be obtained free of charge from Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre via www.ccdc.cam.ac.uk/data_request/cif.
elements.clean_text: Single crystal XRD of 1(2-PrOH)* was measured at 173 K by R-AXIS RAPID (Rigaku) with monochromated Cu Kα radiation at 50 mA and 250 kV. The structure was solved by the direct method (SIR97) and refined by full matrix least-squares on F 2 (SHELX97). Anisotropic displacement parameters were assigned to all the non-hydrogen atoms. The crystal structure of 1(2-PrOH)* can be basically expected to be the same to that of 1(2-PrOH) supported by the similarity of XRD patterns although there are slight shifts of the diffraction peaks in XRD patterns of them due to the different measurement temperatures. Crystallographic parameters of 1, 1(CO  2  ), 1(MeOH), 1(EtOH), 1(1-PrOH), 1(2-PrOH), and 1(2-PrOH)* are summarized in . CCDC 1479332 (1(CO  2  )), 1479333 (1), 1479334 (1(EtOH)), and 1484688 (1(2-PrOH)*) contain the supplementary crystallographic data. These data can be obtained free of charge from Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre via www.ccdc.cam.ac.uk/data_request/cif.

The lattice parameters were obtained in the Le Bail method.

The gas sorption measurements were performed by using automatic volumetric adsorption apparatuses (BELSORP 28, BELSORP 18; MicrotracBEL Corp.). A known weight (ca. 50 mg) of an as-synthesized sample was placed in a sample cell. Before all the measurements, the samples were degassed at 413 K under vacuum (P < 10 –1 Pa) for 2 h. Pretreatment at 343 K under vacuum (P < 10 –1 Pa) for 2 h also gave similar effect on sorption properties of the MOF confirmed by the measurements of CO2 sorption isotherms.
elements.clean_text: The gas sorption measurements were performed by using automatic volumetric adsorption apparatuses (BELSORP 28, BELSORP 18; MicrotracBEL Corp.). A known weight (ca. 50 mg) of an as-synthesized sample was placed in a sample cell. Before all the measurements, the samples were degassed at 413 K under vacuum (P < 10 -1 Pa) for 2 h. Pretreatment at 343 K under vacuum (P < 10 -1 Pa) for 2 h also gave similar effect on sorption properties of the MOF confirmed by the measurements of CO2 sorption isotherms.

elements.content: The structure of the guest-free form (1) solved by ab initio powder crystal structural analysis is shown in . The final Rietveld plot of 1 is shown in a. In the obtained crystal structure, all the copper­(II) sites are crystallographically equivalent and octahedrally coordinated by four nitrogen atoms of the four bpp ligands at the equatorial positions and two fluorine atoms of the two BF4 anions at the axial positions with Jahn–Teller distortion (b and ). Copper­(II) ions are bridged by bpp ligands to form a 1D chain structure along the b-axis with small rings of 12.5802(4) Å × 5.993(10) Å (, parts b and c). The 1D chains are aligned along the b-axis to form quasi-2D sheets by a π–π interaction between bpp ligands of 3.38 Å, and BF4 anions are located on both the sides of the layers in a quasi-hexagonal arrangement. The hexagonal space surrounded by BF4 anions, which is schematically shown in , should work as sorption sites. The effective size of the hexagonal cavity is estimated to be 7.1–9.2 Å by subtracting the van der Waals radii of F atom from the distances between BF4 anions oppositely located. Each quasi-2D sheet stacks in the [201̅] direction with an interlayer distance of 7.30 Å in an interdigitated manner (, parts d and e), resulting in an alternation of Cu–bpp layers and BF4 layers. Effective distances between adjacent BF4 anions are estimated to be 1.4–2.2 Å, indicating a latent porous structure in 1.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

The structure of the guest-free form (1) solved by ab initio powder crystal structural analysis is shown in . The final Rietveld plot of 1 is shown in a. In the obtained crystal structure, all the copper(II) sites are crystallographically equivalent and octahedrally coordinated by four nitrogen atoms of the four bpp ligands at the equatorial positions and two fluorine atoms of the two BF4 anions at the axial positions with Jahn-Teller distortion (b and ). Copper(II) ions are bridged by bpp ligands to form a 1D chain structure along the b-axis with small rings of 12.5802(4) Å × 5.993(10) Å (, parts b and c). The 1D chains are aligned along the b-axis to form quasi-2D sheets by a π-π interaction between bpp ligands of 3.38 Å, and BF4 anions are located on both the sides of the layers in a quasi-hexagonal arrangement. The hexagonal space surrounded by BF4 anions, which is schematically shown in , should work as sorption sites. The effective size of the hexagonal cavity is estimated to be 7.1-9.2 Å by subtracting the van der Waals radii of F atom from the distances between BF4 anions oppositely located. Each quasi-2D sheet stacks in the [201̅] direction with an interlayer distance of 7.30 Å in an interdigitated manner (, parts d and e), resulting in an alternation of Cu-bpp layers and BF4 layers. Effective distances between adjacent BF4 anions are estimated to be 1.4-2.2 Å, indicating a latent porous structure in 1.

elements.content: (a) Final Rietveld plot of 1 with a range of 3–35 (2θ/°). Red points and green lines represent the observed and calculated diffraction patterns, respectively. Blue line represents the residual error and green tick marks represent the Bragg peak positions. (b) Local structure around a Cu­(II) ion in 1. (c) Top view of quasi-2D sheets. BF4 anions are shown in CPK model. (d) Side view of quasi-2D sheets. (e) Perspective view of overall structure of 1 along the b-axis. (c–e) Copper ions, bpp ligands, and BF4 anions are shown in a stick model except for BF4 anions in part c (Cu, brown; C, gray; N, blue; B, pink; F, light green).

Blue line represents the residual error and green tick marks represent the Bragg peak positions. (b) Local structure around a Cu(II) ion in 1. (c) Top view of quasi-2D sheets. BF4 anions are shown in CPK model. (d) Side view of quasi-2D sheets. (e) Perspective view of overall structure of 1 along the b-axis. (c-e) Copper ions, bpp ligands, and BF4 anions are shown in a stick model except for BF4 anions in part c (Cu, brown; C, gray; N, blue; B, pink; F, light green).

In situ synchrotron XRD patterns of 1 with CO2 and N2 gas loading at several pressures below 1 atm are shown in and Figure S1. In the case of the CO2 loading at 273 K, no structural change occurs at 40 kPa or lower pressures, and an abrupt structural change is observed at 67 kPa in a pressurization process. In the following depressurization process, the XRD pattern is basically maintained down to 40 kPa from 101 kPa, and a structural recovery to the original state is observed at 13 kPa (a). Because the XRD change is well consistent with the CO2 sorption (b), it is clear that CO2 sorption on 1 occurs accompanying with dynamic structural transformation. On the other hand, the XRD patterns of 1 do not change on the N2 loading at all because 1 sorbs no N2 at these conditions. These results indicate that 1 shows selective molecular sorption properties based on guest-dependent structural transformation.
elements.clean_text: In situ synchrotron XRD patterns of 1 with CO2 and N2 gas loading at several pressures below 1 atm are shown in  and Figure S1. In the case of the CO2 loading at 273 K, no structural change occurs at 40 kPa or lower pressures, and an abrupt structural change is observed at 67 kPa in a pressurization process. In the following depressurization process, the XRD pattern is basically maintained down to 40 kPa from 101 kPa, and a structural recovery to the original state is observed at 13 kPa (a). Because the XRD change is well consistent with the CO2 sorption (b), it is clear that CO2 sorption on 1 occurs accompanying with dynamic structural transformation. On the other hand, the XRD patterns of 1 do not change on the N2 loading at all because 1 sorbs no N2 at these conditions. These results indicate that 1 shows selective molecular sorption properties based on guest-dependent structural transformation.

elements.content: (a) Synchrotron XRD patterns with a range of 4–10 (2θ/deg) under different CO2 loadings at 273 K (λ = 0.80008(2) Å). (b) CO2 sorption isotherms at 273 K. Open and closed symbols represent adsorption and desorption, respectively.
elements.clean_text: 3  (a) Synchrotron XRD patterns with a range of 4-10 (2θ/deg) under different CO2 loadings at 273 K (λ = 0.80008(2) Å). (b) CO2 sorption isotherms at 273 K. Open and closed symbols represent adsorption and desorption, respectively.

elements.content: The final Rietveld plot of 1­(CO 2 ) is shown in Figure S2. The results of the structural analysis indicate that 1D chains, which are composed of Cu­(II) ions and bridging bpp ligands, are accumulated to form quasi-2D layers and the layers are stacked each other with an interlayer distance of 7.36 Å in 1­(CO 2 ) (). The framework structure of 1­(CO 2 ) is similar to that of 1, though slight change is observed in unit cell parameters (). Through the CO2 accommodation, the unit cell parameters a and c increase 0.80% and 2.20%, respectively, and the parameter b decreases 0.91%, resulting in 3.26% increase of the unit cell volume. Sorbed CO2 molecules were observed in an ordered arrangement by the Rietveld analysis. Carbon dioxide molecules are trapped in the quasi-hexagonal cavities surrounded by six BF4 anions with the effective size of 8.3–8.9 Å (a). The good fit of the experimental and simulated patterns with the CO2 occupancy (0.7) less than one in the Rietveld analysis implies that 1 has a potential to sorb more CO2. Actually, it was reported that 1 sorbs 1.4 times more CO2 at 0.93 MPa and 298 K than the amount sorbed at 100 kPa and 273 K. Carbon dioxide molecules are located near BF4 anions in the cavities with a distance of 2.61(6) Å between a C atom of CO2 and a F atom of BF4 anion, and are inclined at an angle of 59.6° against the quasi-2D sheet. Interestingly, each sorbed CO2 molecule makes a pair with another BF4 anion, resulting in overall quasi-hexagonal arrangement of CO2 molecules as shown in a. The BF4 anions in the hexagonal arrangement are located closely at effective distances of 0.7–2.4 Å, which are smaller than 3.3 Å, the kinetic diameter of CO2 molecule. This means that the CO2 molecules are accommodated in the closed cavities.

Through the CO2 accommodation, the unit cell parameters a and c increase 0.80% and 2.20%, respectively, and the parameter b decreases 0.91%, resulting in 3.26% increase of the unit cell volume. Sorbed CO2 molecules were observed in an ordered arrangement by the Rietveld analysis. Carbon dioxide molecules are trapped in the quasi-hexagonal cavities surrounded by six BF4 anions with the effective size of 8.3-8.9 Å (a). The good fit of the experimental and simulated patterns with the CO2 occupancy (0.7) less than one in the Rietveld analysis implies that 1 has a potential to sorb more CO2. Actually, it was reported that 1 sorbs 1.4 times more CO2 at 0.93 MPa and 298 K than the amount sorbed at 100 kPa and 273 K. Carbon dioxide molecules are located near BF4 anions in the cavities with a distance of 2.61(6) Å between a C atom of CO2 and a F atom of BF4 anion, and are inclined at an angle of 59.6° against the quasi-2D sheet. Interestingly, each sorbed CO2 molecule makes a pair with another BF4 anion, resulting in overall quasi-hexagonal arrangement of CO2 molecules as shown in a. The BF4 anions in the hexagonal arrangement are located closely at effective distances of 0.7-2.4 Å, which are smaller than 3.3 Å, the kinetic diameter of CO2 molecule. This means that the CO2 molecules are accommodated in the closed cavities.

elements.content: Crystal structure of 1­(CO 2 ). (a) Top view of quasi-2D sheets. (b) Side view of quasi-2D sheets. (c) Perspective view of overall structure along the b-axis. In all the figures, CO2 molecules are shown in CPK model, and BF4 anions are shown in CPK model (a) and stick model (b and c). Copper ions and bpp ligands are shown in a stick model in all the figures (Cu, brown; C, gray; N, blue; B, pink; F, light green; O, red).
elements.clean_text: 4  Crystal structure of 1(CO  2  ). (a) Top view of quasi-2D sheets. (b) Side view of quasi-2D sheets. (c) Perspective view of overall structure along the b-axis. In all the figures, CO2 molecules are shown in CPK model, and BF4 anions are shown in CPK model (a) and stick model (b and c). Copper ions and bpp ligands are shown in a stick model in all the figures (Cu, brown; C, gray; N, blue; B, pink; F, light green; O, red).

elements.content: By comparing the structures of 1 and 1­(CO 2 ), it is possible to propose a CO2 sorption mechanism as follows. Initially, the 1D MOF is nonporous with the hexagonal cavities, and makes pore windows to the cavities for CO2 molecules at a certain sorption condition. Carbon dioxide molecules are sorbed through the windows and tend to make pairs with BF4 anions to form a hexagonal arrangement of CO2 molecules. In the sorption process, the overall structure with CO2 molecules is stabilized by the energetic gain from CO2 sorption larger than the energetic loss from destabilization of the framework. In the desorption process, trapped CO2 molecules are desorbed from the cavities with structural change to the initial form. That is, the 1D MOF is destabilized to form a structure with open pores induced by depressurization, and CO2 molecules are desorbed at a lower pressure than the adsorption pressure. Then, the framework is rearranged to stabilize the structure without CO2 molecules, which results in the formation of the initial closed state. It is noteworthy that the CO2 accommodation state has no open channels. This is completely different from many flexible MOFs such as MIL-53, Co­(BDP), Cu­(dhbc)2(bpy)2 (dhbc =2,5-dihydroxybenzoate), ELM-11, and similar 1D MOFs, which have open channels accessible from outside in sorption states.
elements.clean_text: By comparing the structures of 1 and 1(CO  2  ), it is possible to propose a CO2 sorption mechanism as follows. Initially, the 1D MOF is nonporous with the hexagonal cavities, and makes pore windows to the cavities for CO2 molecules at a certain sorption condition. Carbon dioxide molecules are sorbed through the windows and tend to make pairs with BF4 anions to form a hexagonal arrangement of CO2 molecules. In the sorption process, the overall structure with CO2 molecules is stabilized by the energetic gain from CO2 sorption larger than the energetic loss from destabilization of the framework. In the desorption process, trapped CO2 molecules are desorbed from the cavities with structural change to the initial form. That is, the 1D MOF is destabilized to form a structure with open pores induced by depressurization, and CO2 molecules are desorbed at a lower pressure than the adsorption pressure. Then, the framework is rearranged to stabilize the structure without CO2 molecules, which results in the formation of the initial closed state. It is noteworthy that the CO2 accommodation state has no open channels. This is completely different from many flexible MOFs such as MIL-53, Co(BDP), Cu(dhbc)2(bpy)2  (dhbc =2,5-dihydroxybenzoate), ELM-11, and similar 1D MOFs, which have open channels accessible from outside in sorption states.

elements.content: To investigate the sorption states with different guests, crystal structures of the MOF with some guests were investigated. Single crystals of 1 accommodating 2-propanol (1­(2-PrOH)*), which is similar to 1­(2-PrOH) confirmed by XRD measurements, were successfully obtained by reacting an aqueous solution of Cu­(BF4)2 and a 2-propanol solution of bpp at a room temperature. Furthermore, the crystal structure of the ethanol-accommodated MOF (1­(EtOH)) was solved by powder X-ray structural analysis in a way similar to the case of 1­(CO 2 ). The final Rietveld plot of 1­(EtOH) is shown in Figure S3. In 1­(2-PrOH)*, the fundamental structure is similar to that of 1, which is the guest-free state, and 1D chains formed by Cu­(II) ions and bpp ligands are aligned along the b axis. The 1D chains are stabilized by π–π interaction between bpp ligands of 3.5–3.6 Å, which are slightly longer than that in 1, implying loose packing of the 1D chains in 1­(2-PrOH)* compared with 1. BF4 anions are disordered in two sites, and in both the sites fluorine atoms in the BF4 anions have hydrogen bondings with hydrogen atoms in propylene chains in bpp ligands (2.8–2.9 Å). Both the crystal structural analyses of 1­(2-PrOH)* and 1­(EtOH) reveal that 1 accommodates two guest molecules in each quasi-hexagonal cavity (). The accommodated 2-propanol or ethanol molecules are located in hexagonal arrangements in the structures, which are similar to CO2 molecules in 1­(CO 2 ). In each cavity, two ethanol or 2-propanol molecules are stabilized by orienting not only both the hydrophobic parts of the molecules to face each other but also the hydroxyl groups toward BF4 anions. Through the accommodation of the guest species, 1 expands the unit cell volume. shows the relationship between the unit cell volumes of the crystals and the volumes of the corresponding guest molecules calculated by ChemOffice software. The relationship clearly shows that larger molecule induces larger unit cell volume, indicating induced-fit properties of 1.

Single crystals of 1 accommodating 2-propanol (1(2-PrOH)*), which is similar to 1(2-PrOH) confirmed by XRD measurements, were successfully obtained by reacting an aqueous solution of Cu(BF4)2 and a 2-propanol solution of bpp at a room temperature. Furthermore, the crystal structure of the ethanol-accommodated MOF (1(EtOH)) was solved by powder X-ray structural analysis in a way similar to the case of 1(CO  2  ). The final Rietveld plot of 1(EtOH) is shown in Figure S3. In 1(2-PrOH)*, the fundamental structure is similar to that of 1, which is the guest-free state, and 1D chains formed by Cu(II) ions and bpp ligands are aligned along the b axis. The 1D chains are stabilized by π-π interaction between bpp ligands of 3.5-3.6 Å, which are slightly longer than that in 1, implying loose packing of the 1D chains in 1(2-PrOH)* compared with 1. BF4 anions are disordered in two sites, and in both the sites fluorine atoms in the BF4 anions have hydrogen bondings with hydrogen atoms in propylene chains in bpp ligands (2.8-2.9 Å). Both the crystal structural analyses of 1(2-PrOH)* and 1(EtOH) reveal that 1 accommodates two guest molecules in each quasi-hexagonal cavity (). The accommodated 2-propanol or ethanol molecules are located in hexagonal arrangements in the structures, which are similar to CO2 molecules in 1(CO  2  ). In each cavity, two ethanol or 2-propanol molecules are stabilized by orienting not only both the hydrophobic parts of the molecules to face each other but also the hydroxyl groups toward BF4 anions. Through the accommodation of the guest species, 1 expands the unit cell volume.  shows the relationship between the unit cell volumes of the crystals and the volumes of the corresponding guest molecules calculated by ChemOffice software. The relationship clearly shows that larger molecule induces larger unit cell volume, indicating induced-fit properties of 1.

elements.content: Vapor sorption isotherms of several alcohols (methanol, ethanol, 1-propanol, 2-propanol, and 1-butanol) on 1 measured at 303 K are shown in . It is clear that 1 shows gate-type adsorption/desorption isotherms for all the alcohols except for 1-butanol because no uptake in low relative pressure regions and abrupt uptakes at higher specific pressures. The relative pressures of all the gate-type adsorption uptakes are between 0.01 and 0.1 (b). In the desorption processes, steep drops at relative pressures lower than the uptake pressures were observed, and sorbed alcohol molecules were completely desorbed, indicating physical sorption on 1. Therefore, definite hysteresis loops were observed in all the isotherms. The sorbed amounts of the alcohols at P/P 0 ≈ 1 are shown in . The sorbed amounts of ethanol, 1-propanol, and 2-propanol correspond to approximately two molecules per copper atom, and the amount of methanol is 1.5 times larger than that of ethanol and propanol. As revealed by the structural analyses of the alcohol-sorbed states, 1­(EtOH) and 1­(2-PrOH)*, two guest molecules are packed in each quasi-hexagonal cavity to form the hexagonal arrangements. Because of the similarity of 1-propanol to ethanol or 2-propanol in size and shape and of the similar sorbed amounts of them, C2–C3 alcohols should be sorbed in the cavities of 1 in a similar manner as far as the interlayer void spaces permit. In the case of methanol, probably three molecules are sorbed in each hexagonal cavitiy in the MOF, which should be possible because of the smaller molecular size of methanol than those of the other alcohols.
elements.clean_text: Vapor sorption isotherms of several alcohols (methanol, ethanol, 1-propanol, 2-propanol, and 1-butanol) on 1 measured at 303 K are shown in . It is clear that 1 shows gate-type adsorption/desorption isotherms for all the alcohols except for 1-butanol because no uptake in low relative pressure regions and abrupt uptakes at higher specific pressures. The relative pressures of all the gate-type adsorption uptakes are between 0.01 and 0.1 (b). In the desorption processes, steep drops at relative pressures lower than the uptake pressures were observed, and sorbed alcohol molecules were completely desorbed, indicating physical sorption on 1. Therefore, definite hysteresis loops were observed in all the isotherms. The sorbed amounts of the alcohols at P/P 0 ~ 1 are shown in . The sorbed amounts of ethanol, 1-propanol, and 2-propanol correspond to approximately two molecules per copper atom, and the amount of methanol is 1.5 times larger than that of ethanol and propanol. As revealed by the structural analyses of the alcohol-sorbed states, 1(EtOH) and 1(2-PrOH)*, two guest molecules are packed in each quasi-hexagonal cavity to form the hexagonal arrangements. Because of the similarity of 1-propanol to ethanol or 2-propanol in size and shape and of the similar sorbed amounts of them, C2-C3 alcohols should be sorbed in the cavities of 1 in a similar manner as far as the interlayer void spaces permit. In the case of methanol, probably three molecules are sorbed in each hexagonal cavitiy in the MOF, which should be possible because of the smaller molecular size of methanol than those of the other alcohols.

elements.content: Sorption isotherms of methanol (black circle), ethanol (green rectangle), 1-propanol (blue triangle), 2-propanol (red square), and 1-butanol (black cross) at 303 K (a) in a linear relative pressure scale and (b) in a logarithmic relative pressure scale. Filled and open symbols represent adsorption and desorption branches, respectively.
elements.clean_text: 7  Sorption isotherms of methanol (black circle), ethanol (green rectangle), 1-propanol (blue triangle), 2-propanol (red square), and 1-butanol (black cross) at 303 K (a) in a linear relative pressure scale and (b) in a logarithmic relative pressure scale. Filled and open symbols represent adsorption and desorption branches, respectively.

elements.content:
Amounts of Several Alcohols and CO<sub>2</sub> Sorbed on <bold>1</bold> adsorbate amount sorbed/mg g–1 R–OH/Cu or CO2/Cu temp/K methanol 156 3.1 303 ethanol 133 1.8 303 1-propanol 155 1.6 303 2-propanol 178 1.9 303 CO2 95 1.3 273

R is CH3 for methanol, C2H5 for ethanol, and C3H8 for propanol.

To investigate sorption mechanism of C1–C3 alcohols, in situ synchrotron XRD patterns of 1 were measured at 303 K with alcohol vapor loadings ( and Figure S4). As is the case with CO2 adsorption/desorption, definite structural changes are observed through ethanol adsorption/desorption (Figure S4). By increasing the loading pressure of ethanol from 0.7 to 6.7 kPa, structural change is observed. The following depressurization from 6.7 to 0.7 kPa causes no phase transformation and further decrease in ethanol pressure to 0.4 kPa induces structural change to recover the initial phase 1 because of the sorption hysteresis. By comparing the structures of 1 and 1­(EtOH), the change is definitely believed to be structural transformation between the empty form and the accommodation form. Vapor loadings of methanol, 1-propanol, and 2-propanol also induce dynamic structural transformations, and on the other hand 1-butanol loading induces no structural change (). These results strongly suggest that the sorption of the C1–C3 alcohols on 1 occurs accompanying with dynamic structural transformation.
elements.clean_text: To investigate sorption mechanism of C1-C3 alcohols, in situ synchrotron XRD patterns of 1 were measured at 303 K with alcohol vapor loadings ( and Figure S4). As is the case with CO2 adsorption/desorption, definite structural changes are observed through ethanol adsorption/desorption (Figure S4). By increasing the loading pressure of ethanol from 0.7 to 6.7 kPa, structural change is observed. The following depressurization from 6.7 to 0.7 kPa causes no phase transformation and further decrease in ethanol pressure to 0.4 kPa induces structural change to recover the initial phase 1 because of the sorption hysteresis. By comparing the structures of 1 and 1(EtOH), the change is definitely believed to be structural transformation between the empty form and the accommodation form. Vapor loadings of methanol, 1-propanol, and 2-propanol also induce dynamic structural transformations, and on the other hand 1-butanol loading induces no structural change (). These results strongly suggest that the sorption of the C1-C3 alcohols on 1 occurs accompanying with dynamic structural transformation.

elements.content: As mentioned above, 1 allows no sorption of 1-butanol at 303 K but, however, sorbs C1–C3 alcohols at different uptake pressures. On the basis of the result of the synchrotron XRD experiments mentioned above, it is apparent that no structural transformation by 1-butanol vapor is a critical reason why 1 has no 1-butanol uptake. The structure of 1 has no open pore, and therefore, the pore-opening process is necessary for molecular accommodation. It is believed that host–guest interactions including van der Waals interaction play important roles for pore-opening of flexible MOFs. For example, ELM-11 shows structural transformation from a latent porous form to an open form through CO2 sorption; however, H2, which has a smaller van der Waals interaction than that of CO2, induces no structural change on ELM-11, resulting in no uptake of H2. Also, in the case of 1, H2 molecules was not sorbed, though CO2 molecules are sorbed. If the van der Waals interaction is predominant for the pore-opening of 1, 1-butanol should be sorbed because 1-butanol has a larger van der Waals interaction than that of CO2. These considerations suggest other key factors to induce the sorption properties of 1. In view of shapes of linear alcohol molecules, the minimum dimension of 1-butanol is almost the same as those of the other linear alcohols such as ethanol and 1-propanol, and therefore, pore windows of 1, which is assumed to be dynamically opened and closed through an sorption process, should be large enough to pass 1-butanol molecules. Furthermore, the cavities in 1 can accommodate 1-butanol because of the slightly larger space of the cavity than a 1-butanol molecule. However, the results of sorption experiments on 1 is inconsistent with these assumptions. One possible explanation of the 1-butanol sorption properties of 1 is poor fitting of 1-butanol in the cavity, which is observed in cage-type porous materials as length dependent sorption/exclusion. The linear alcohols shorter than 1-butanol can be sorbed, and, however, 1-butanol or longer alcohols may not fit the hexagonal cavity resulting in exclusion of adsorbates. This is a rare example of molecular recognition based on the fitness of molecular length and cavity size in flexible MOFs. To the best of our knowledge, it is the first report about molecular-length-dependent gate adsorption on flexible MOFs. The concept of molecular recognition sorption/separation should be also useful for other porous materials. Development of porous materials with tailor-made cavities should be important for the progress of sorption/separation technology of target molecules.

On the basis of the result of the synchrotron XRD experiments mentioned above, it is apparent that no structural transformation by 1-butanol vapor is a critical reason why 1 has no 1-butanol uptake. The structure of 1 has no open pore, and therefore, the pore-opening process is necessary for molecular accommodation. It is believed that host-guest interactions including van der Waals interaction play important roles for pore-opening of flexible MOFs. For example, ELM-11 shows structural transformation from a latent porous form to an open form through CO2 sorption; however, H2, which has a smaller van der Waals interaction than that of CO2, induces no structural change on ELM-11, resulting in no uptake of H2. Also, in the case of 1, H2 molecules was not sorbed, though CO2 molecules are sorbed. If the van der Waals interaction is predominant for the pore-opening of 1, 1-butanol should be sorbed because 1-butanol has a larger van der Waals interaction than that of CO2. These considerations suggest other key factors to induce the sorption properties of 1. In view of shapes of linear alcohol molecules, the minimum dimension of 1-butanol is almost the same as those of the other linear alcohols such as ethanol and 1-propanol, and therefore, pore windows of 1, which is assumed to be dynamically opened and closed through an sorption process, should be large enough to pass 1-butanol molecules. Furthermore, the cavities in 1 can accommodate 1-butanol because of the slightly larger space of the cavity than a 1-butanol molecule. However, the results of sorption experiments on 1 is inconsistent with these assumptions. One possible explanation of the 1-butanol sorption properties of 1 is poor fitting of 1-butanol in the cavity, which is observed in cage-type porous materials as length dependent sorption/exclusion. The linear alcohols shorter than 1-butanol can be sorbed, and, however, 1-butanol or longer alcohols may not fit the hexagonal cavity resulting in exclusion of adsorbates. This is a rare example of molecular recognition based on the fitness of molecular length and cavity size in flexible MOFs. To the best of our knowledge, it is the first report about molecular-length-dependent gate adsorption on flexible MOFs. The concept of molecular recognition sorption/separation should be also useful for other porous materials. Development of porous materials with tailor-made cavities should be important for the progress of sorption/separation technology of target molecules.

elements.content: On the basis of all of our investigation, several key factors to enhance sorption properties of flexible MOFs are proposed. During molecular sorption, the closed form of 1 with the quasi-hexagonal cavities makes effective pore windows dynamically depending on guest species, resulting in selective sorption. The crystal structure of the accommodation state has no effective channels, which prevent other molecules from entering the cavities. There are many examples about structural change from a closed form to an open form accompanied by gas sorption. However, it is rare to explain the importance of pore-closing process for molecular selectivity as well as pore-opening process in sorption processes. Furthermore, molecular recognition property of flexible MOFs is important for selective sorption/separation. Reversely, misfit of guest molecules in sorption sites in host frameworks suppresses sorption of the corresponding guest species. Therefore, it is a useful way to control the shape of nanospace in flexible MOFs not only for positive sorption of targeted molecules but also negative sorption of undesired molecules.
elements.clean_text: On the basis of all of our investigation, several key factors to enhance sorption properties of flexible MOFs are proposed. During molecular sorption, the closed form of 1 with the quasi-hexagonal cavities makes effective pore windows dynamically depending on guest species, resulting in selective sorption. The crystal structure of the accommodation state has no effective channels, which prevent other molecules from entering the cavities. There are many examples about structural change from a closed form to an open form accompanied by gas sorption. However, it is rare to explain the importance of pore-closing process for molecular selectivity as well as pore-opening process in sorption processes. Furthermore, molecular recognition property of flexible MOFs is important for selective sorption/separation. Reversely, misfit of guest molecules in sorption sites in host frameworks suppresses sorption of the corresponding guest species. Therefore, it is a useful way to control the shape of nanospace in flexible MOFs not only for positive sorption of targeted molecules but also negative sorption of undesired molecules.

elements.content: Structural analyses of a flexible 1D MOF [Cu­(BF4)2(bpp)2] with/without guest molecules were performed by synchrotron powder X-ray diffraction analysis and single crystal structural analysis. The guest-free MOF is composed of 1D chain motifs accumulated to form quasi-2D layers, resulting in a quasi-layered compound. The guest-free MOF has no open pore and has latent interlayer hexagonal cavities surrounded by six BF4 anions. The MOF dynamically sorbs CO2 molecules in the cavities at 273 K and has no N2 sorption at the same temperature, which stems from guest-dependent dynamic structural transformation. The MOF shows gate-type adsorption isotherms of the C1–C3 alcohols with hysteresis loops and almost no sorption of 1-butanol at 303 K. The sorption of the C1–C3 alcohols are induced by dynamic structural transformation of the flexible host framework, and the alcohol molecules are packed in the cavities in a similar manner of CO2, as confirmed by in situ synchrotron XRD experiments. Through these investigations, the following sorption mechanism of the MOF is proposed: (i) The initial state of the MOF is nonporous with latent cavities and the MOF makes pore windows dynamically by host–guest interaction. (ii) Molecules are selectively sorbed in the cavities. In the sorption process, the overall structure with guest molecules is stabilized by the energetic gain from guest sorption larger than the energetic loss from destabilization of the framework. In the case of the flexible MOF, the sorption properties should be synergetically enhanced by accumulation of several key properties; it sorbs molecules selectively with pore-opening and blocks other species by pore-closing.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

Structural analyses of a flexible 1D MOF [Cu(BF4)2(bpp)2] with/without guest molecules were performed by synchrotron powder X-ray diffraction analysis and single crystal structural analysis. The guest-free MOF is composed of 1D chain motifs accumulated to form quasi-2D layers, resulting in a quasi-layered compound. The guest-free MOF has no open pore and has latent interlayer hexagonal cavities surrounded by six BF4 anions. The MOF dynamically sorbs CO2 molecules in the cavities at 273 K and has no N2 sorption at the same temperature, which stems from guest-dependent dynamic structural transformation. The MOF shows gate-type adsorption isotherms of the C1-C3 alcohols with hysteresis loops and almost no sorption of 1-butanol at 303 K. The sorption of the C1-C3 alcohols are induced by dynamic structural transformation of the flexible host framework, and the alcohol molecules are packed in the cavities in a similar manner of CO2, as confirmed by in situ synchrotron XRD experiments. Through these investigations, the following sorption mechanism of the MOF is proposed: (i) The initial state of the MOF is nonporous with latent cavities and the MOF makes pore windows dynamically by host-guest interaction. (ii) Molecules are selectively sorbed in the cavities. In the sorption process, the overall structure with guest molecules is stabilized by the energetic gain from guest sorption larger than the energetic loss from destabilization of the framework. In the case of the flexible MOF, the sorption properties should be synergetically enhanced by accumulation of several key properties; it sorbs molecules selectively with pore-opening and blocks other species by pore-closing.

cln_elements.content: Single crystals of {[Cu­(BF4)2(bpp)2]·2­(CH3CH­(OH)­CH3)} (1­(2-PrOH)*), which contain 2-propanol as guest molecules, were synthesized as follows. An asterisk is put on the name to refer to single crystal results to distinguish from powder crystal results. A 2-propanol solution of bpp (80 mM, 5 mL) was added onto an aqueous solution of Cu­(BF4)2·6H2O (40 mM, 5 mL) after adding 2-propanol (2 mL) as an intermediate solvent in a test tube at a room temperature. After a few days, purple crystals were grown on the tube wall, and then collected by suction filtration and washed with 2-propanol.
cln_elements.clean_text: Single crystals of {[Cu(BF4)2(bpp)2]⋅2(CH3CH(OH)CH3)} (1(2-PrOH)*), which contain 2-propanol as guest molecules, were synthesized as follows. An asterisk is put on the name to refer to single crystal results to distinguish from powder crystal results. A 2-propanol solution of bpp (80 mM, 5 mL) was added onto an aqueous solution of Cu(BF4)2⋅6H2O (40 mM, 5 mL) after adding 2-propanol (2 mL) as an intermediate solvent in a test tube at a room temperature. After a few days, purple crystals were grown on the tube wall, and then collected by suction filtration and washed with 2-propanol.

Amounts of Several Alcohols and CO<sub>2</sub> Sorbed on <bold>1</bold> adsorbate amount sorbed/mg g–1 R–OH/Cu or CO2/Cu temp/K methanol 156 3.1 303 ethanol 133 1.8 303 1-propanol 155 1.6 303 2-propanol 178 1.9 303 CO2 95 1.3 273

R is CH3 for methanol, C2H5 for ethanol, and C3H8 for propanol.

cln_elements.content: Schematic model of the selective dynamic accommodation process. Green blocks represent BF4 anions. Red circle and gray octahedron mean sorbable and nonsorbable species, respectively.
cln_elements.clean_text: 1  Schematic model of the selective dynamic accommodation process. Green blocks represent BF4 anions. Red circle and gray octahedron mean sorbable and nonsorbable species, respectively.

cln_elements.content: (a) Final Rietveld plot of 1 with a range of 3–35 (2θ/°). Red points and green lines represent the observed and calculated diffraction patterns, respectively. Blue line represents the residual error and green tick marks represent the Bragg peak positions. (b) Local structure around a Cu­(II) ion in 1. (c) Top view of quasi-2D sheets. BF4 anions are shown in CPK model. (d) Side view of quasi-2D sheets. (e) Perspective view of overall structure of 1 along the b-axis. (c–e) Copper ions, bpp ligands, and BF4 anions are shown in a stick model except for BF4 anions in part c (Cu, brown; C, gray; N, blue; B, pink; F, light green).
cln_elements.clean_text: 2  (a) Final Rietveld plot of 1 with a range of 3-35 (2θ/°). Red points and green lines represent the observed and calculated diffraction patterns, respectively. Blue line represents the residual error and green tick marks represent the Bragg peak positions. (b) Local structure around a Cu(II) ion in 1. (c) Top view of quasi-2D sheets. BF4 anions are shown in CPK model. (d) Side view of quasi-2D sheets. (e) Perspective view of overall structure of 1 along the b-axis. (c-e) Copper ions, bpp ligands, and BF4 anions are shown in a stick model except for BF4 anions in part c (Cu, brown; C, gray; N, blue; B, pink; F, light green).

cln_elements.content: (a) Synchrotron XRD patterns with a range of 4–10 (2θ/deg) under different CO2 loadings at 273 K (λ = 0.80008(2) Å). (b) CO2 sorption isotherms at 273 K. Open and closed symbols represent adsorption and desorption, respectively.
cln_elements.clean_text: 3  (a) Synchrotron XRD patterns with a range of 4-10 (2θ/deg) under different CO2 loadings at 273 K (λ = 0.80008(2) Å). (b) CO2 sorption isotherms at 273 K. Open and closed symbols represent adsorption and desorption, respectively.

cln_elements.content: Crystal structure of 1­(CO 2 ). (a) Top view of quasi-2D sheets. (b) Side view of quasi-2D sheets. (c) Perspective view of overall structure along the b-axis. In all the figures, CO2 molecules are shown in CPK model, and BF4 anions are shown in CPK model (a) and stick model (b and c). Copper ions and bpp ligands are shown in a stick model in all the figures (Cu, brown; C, gray; N, blue; B, pink; F, light green; O, red).
cln_elements.clean_text: 4  Crystal structure of 1(CO  2  ). (a) Top view of quasi-2D sheets. (b) Side view of quasi-2D sheets. (c) Perspective view of overall structure along the b-axis. In all the figures, CO2 molecules are shown in CPK model, and BF4 anions are shown in CPK model (a) and stick model (b and c). Copper ions and bpp ligands are shown in a stick model in all the figures (Cu, brown; C, gray; N, blue; B, pink; F, light green; O, red).

cln_elements.content: (a) Crystal structure of 1­(2-PrOH)*. (b) Crystal structure of 1­(EtOH). BF4 anions and guest molecules are shown in CPK model, and copper ions and bpp ligands are shown in a stick model (Cu, brown; C, gray; N, blue; B, pink; F, light green; O, red; H, white).
cln_elements.clean_text: 5  (a) Crystal structure of 1(2-PrOH)*. (b) Crystal structure of 1(EtOH). BF4 anions and guest molecules are shown in CPK model, and copper ions and bpp ligands are shown in a stick model (Cu, brown; C, gray; N, blue; B, pink; F, light green; O, red; H, white).

cln_elements.content: Relationship between unit cell volumes and volumes of guest molecules through corresponding guest accommodation.
cln_elements.clean_text: 6  Relationship between unit cell volumes and volumes of guest molecules through corresponding guest accommodation.

cln_elements.content: Sorption isotherms of methanol (black circle), ethanol (green rectangle), 1-propanol (blue triangle), 2-propanol (red square), and 1-butanol (black cross) at 303 K (a) in a linear relative pressure scale and (b) in a logarithmic relative pressure scale. Filled and open symbols represent adsorption and desorption branches, respectively.
cln_elements.clean_text: 7  Sorption isotherms of methanol (black circle), ethanol (green rectangle), 1-propanol (blue triangle), 2-propanol (red square), and 1-butanol (black cross) at 303 K (a) in a linear relative pressure scale and (b) in a logarithmic relative pressure scale. Filled and open symbols represent adsorption and desorption branches, respectively.

cln_elements.content: In situ synchrotron XRD patterns with a range of 3–15 (2θ/deg) under different alcohol vapor loadings at 303 K (λ = 0.79967(2) Å).
cln_elements.clean_text: 8  In situ synchrotron XRD patterns with a range of 3-15 (2θ/deg) under different alcohol vapor loadings at 303 K (λ = 0.79967(2) Å).

metadata.title:
Structural Investigation of a Flexible MOF [Cu(BF4)2(1,3-bis(4-pyridyl)propane)2] Showing Selective Gate
Adsorption with Dynamic Pore-Opening/Pore-Closing Processes
